journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: The Effect of Graft Fixation Angles on Anteroposterior and Rotational Knee Laxity in Double-Bundle Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
title-group.subtitle: Evaluation Using Computerized Navigation

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Tokyo Medical and Dental University Hospital of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Investigation performed at Tokyo Medical and Dental University Hospital of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Hideyuki Koga, MD, PhD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Tokyo Medical and Dental University Hospital of Medicine, 1-5-45 Yushima, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8519, Japan (e-mail: koga.orj@tmd.ac.jp, koga-z@rg7.so-net.ne.jp).

abstract.p: Background: One of the main differences affecting outcome between single-bundle and double-bundle anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstructions may be graft fixation angles and initial force settings; however, there has been little research to investigate these effects in either technique.

Hypothesis: Anteroposterior and rotational knee laxities will be less in double-bundle ACL reconstructions than single-bundle reconstructions, and different graft fixation angles affect knee kinematics and pivot-shift phenomenon in double-bundle ACL reconstructions.

Methods: Eleven patients who underwent double-bundle ACL reconstruction were included in this study. The anteromedial bundle (AMB) and the posterolateral bundle (PLB) were provisionally fixed to a graft tensioning system during surgery. The graft fixation settings were as follows: (1) AMB only at 20° (A20), (2) PLB only at 20° (P20), (3) AMB at 20° and PLB at 0° (A20P0), (4) AMB at 20° and PLB at 20° (A20P20), and (5) AMB at 20° and PLB at 45° (A20P45). All the grafts were tensioned at a constant stress level. Anterior tibial translation (ATT), internal rotation (IR), and external rotation (ER) at 30° and 90° of knee flexion applied with manual maximum load were measured before graft insertion and in each setting using a navigation system. A pivot-shift test was also evaluated manually with modified International Knee Documentation Committee criteria in each setting.

Results: A20 was less constrained than A20P20 and A20P45 in ATT at 30° and less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30°. P20 was less constrained than any other settings in ATT at 30° and less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30°. A20P0 was less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30° and in ER at 30°. Grade 1 pivot-shift phenomenon persisted in 8 cases in P20, in 4 cases in A20, and in 3 cases in A20P0, whereas no case showed a positive pivot-shift result in A20P20 and A20P45.

Conclusion: In this in vivo laboratory model, double-bundle ACL reconstruction with fixation of AMB at 20° and PLB at 20° or 45° restored better stability than single AMB or single PLB reconstruction in which the graft was of smaller size.

Clinical Relevance: In double-bundle ACL reconstruction, fixation of the PLB at 0° might be looser and function worse compared with that of PLB at 20° or 45° when the AMB is fixed at 20°, with the individual variability that should lead to caution until it can be better assessed by surgeons.

body.p: The native anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) does not function as a single bundle and can be anatomically divided into 2 bundles, the anteromedial bundle (AMB) and posterolateral bundle (PLB), which are a continuum in the functional sense. However, ACL reconstructive procedures, which replace only the AMB of the ACL, have involved single-bundle reconstructions until recent days.35,38 While conventional single-bundle ACL reconstructions are considered successful with regard to restoring anterior stability, abnormal rotational motion while walking or running could remain even in stable ACL-reconstructed knees.10,18,26,28

Recent biomechanical studies have revealed that single-bundle AMB reconstruction is insufficient to control a combined rotatory load under certain testing conditions, and the addition of PLB reconstruction produces better rotatory stability.32,35 However, results from clinical studies comparing single-bundle and double-bundle ACL reconstructions (reconstruction of both AMB and PLB) still remain controversial.1,3,17,20,23,34

One of the main reasons might be differences in knee flexion angle at graft fixation in double-bundle ACL reconstruction, as no consensus exists on an optimal setting of AMB and PLB graft fixation angles,6,39 ranging from 0° to 90° for both bundle grafts. Previous biomechanical studies have shown that graft fixation angles affect anteroposterior (AP) and rotational knee laxity in double-bundle ACL reconstruction.7,22,23,31 Moreover, a recent cadaveric study demonstrated that as long as the PLB graft was fixed between 0° and 15°, the AMB graft could be fixed up to 75° without restricting knee laxity, while fixation of the PLB graft at 30° and above significantly overconstrained the knee.2 However, there has been no in vivo study evaluating the effect of graft fixation angles on knee kinematics after double-bundle ACL reconstruction during surgery, and whether fixation of the PLB graft over 30° overconstrains the knee in clinical settings has not been clarified yet.

Another reason might be that individual knee variability affects restoration of stability in double-bundle ACL reconstruction; however, there has been no study evaluating the individual knee variability that affects knee kinematics after double-bundle ACL reconstruction.

Recently, computer-assisted ACL reconstruction has been developed, not only to improve the accuracy and reproducibility of the surgical procedure (tunnel placement)16,30 but also to accurately evaluate the knee kinematics before and after ACL reconstruction.4,14 Using a navigation system, recent studies have compared knee kinematics after double-bundle ACL reconstruction with that after single AMB or PLB reconstruction.8,15,21 These studies have shown some superiority of double-bundle ACL reconstruction in terms of both AP and rotational laxity against manually applied loads21 or during the pivot-shift test,15 while others have shown no differences between double-bundle and single-bundle ACL reconstruction.8

The objectives of this study were to evaluate knee kinematics in single AMB, single PLB, and double-bundle ACL reconstruction as well as to evaluate the effect of graft fixation angles in double-bundle ACL reconstruction, especially focusing on the fixation angle of the PLB graft, using a navigation system. Furthermore, we evaluated the pivot-shift test in each setting to investigate required reconstruction procedures to eliminate the pivot-shift phenomenon. The hypotheses underlying this study were that AP and rotational knee laxities would be less in the double-bundle ACL reconstruction when compared with the single AMB or PLB reconstruction in this study model and that different graft fixation angles would affect knee kinematics and pivot-shift phenomenon in double-bundle ACL reconstruction.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Between August 2010 and November 2010, 35 consecutive patients received double-bundle ACL reconstruction with autologous semitendinosus tendon in our university hospital. Exclusion criteria included revision surgery, knees with osteoarthritis, concomitant ligament tears, history of injuries in the ipsilateral knee, and history of ligamentous injuries in the contralateral knee, and 2 patients were excluded. Among these, 11 patients agreed to be included in this study. The main reasons for the low percentage of participation were that we used the navigation system only for evaluating knee kinematics (not for surgery), and patients (especially female ones) were reluctant to have an additional scar and possible risk of infection. The final group comprised 10 male and 1 female patients with a mean age at the time of surgery of 25 years (range, 20-44 years). All patients had a chronically ACL-deficient knee with a mean period of 8 months (range, 1-41 months) from injury to surgery. One patient had a lateral meniscal injury that was repaired, but no other patient had meniscal injuries that required treatment. This study was approved by our institutional review board, and all the patients provided informed written consent.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: The ACL reconstruction procedure was performed by an experienced surgeon (T.M.) or under his supervision. A standard arthroscopic examination was performed via anteromedial and anterolateral portals. A ruptured ACL was confirmed arthroscopically, and meniscal injury was managed according to the injury status. The remnant tissue of the ruptured ACL was peeled from the lateral wall of the intercondylar notch as little as possible, only enough to detect the posterior bony edge of the lateral wall and the resident’s ridge.9,13 An oblique 3-cm incision was made on the anteromedial tibial surface at the level of the pes anserine. Only the semitendinosus tendon was harvested with an open-loop tendon stripper (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy, Andover, Massachusetts). The harvested tendon was cut into 2 tendons and folded, creating 2 double-stranded bundles of 5.5 cm or more in length looped with the EndoButton CL-BTB (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). The open end of each graft was closed with 2 Krackow sutures and a Kessler suture using No. 2 braided polyester sutures. Before graft passage, the grafts were pretensioned by the Suture Vise with Tensiometer (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy) for at least 10 minutes on the Graftmaster (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy).

Two tibial guide wires were inserted from the anteromedial surface of the tibia at approximately 10 mm above the tibial tubercle level with anatomic landmarks of the ruptured ACL remnant and medial intercondylar eminence. The guide wire for the AMB was aimed 4 to 5 mm posterior to the anterior margin of the ACL remnant and just lateral to the medial intercondylar eminence at an angle of 65° from the joint line in the anterior-posterior radiographic view and at an angle of 50° in the lateral radiographic view. The guide wire for the PLB was aimed just anterior and lateral to the spine of the medial intercondylar eminence at an angle of 45° from the joint line in the anterior-posterior radiographic view and at an angle of 45° in the lateral radiographic view.

Guide wires for the femoral drill holes were inserted via the transtibial tunnel approach in the figure-of-4 position.27 First, the guide wire for the PLB was inserted through the tibial drill hole for the PLB. The center of the femoral drill hole for the PLB was aimed at the 3-o’clock position of the intercondylar clock face in the left knee,36 8 mm anterior to the posterior bony edge of the lateral wall and posterior to the resident’s ridge in flexion position, with arthroscopic observation from the anteromedial portal. A 4.5-mm-diameter tunnel was created in the lateral cortex of the femur using an EndoDrill (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). A second guide wire for the AMB was then inserted through the tibial drill hole for the AMB. The center of the femoral drill hole for the AMB was aimed at the 1:30 position of the intercondylar clock face in the left knee, 6 mm anterior to the posterior bony edge of the lateral wall and posterior to the resident’s ridge in flexion position. A 4.5-mm-diameter tunnel was created in the lateral cortex of the femur using an EndoDrill (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). Thereafter, 25-mm-long femoral sockets for the AMB and PLB with a diameter matched with the graft diameter (AMB: mean, 6.1 mm; range, 6.0-6.5 mm; and PLB: mean, 5.9 mm; range, 5.5-6.5 mm) were created so that independence of each bundle was maintained (Figure 1).

caption.p: (A) Arthroscopic view of femoral tunnels from the anteromedial portal. (B) Arthroscopic view of the reconstructed anterior cruciate ligament from the anterolateral portal.

sec.p: The PLB graft was first inserted through the tibial tunnel to the femoral tunnel using a passing pin. The femoral side of the graft was fixed with the EndoButton CL-BTB (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). The AMB graft was then inserted in the same manner, and the femoral side was also fixed with the EndoButton CL-BTB (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). Each graft was then provisionally fixed to the Stress Equalization (SE) Graft Tensioning System (Linvatec, Largo, Florida) with sutures at the tibial site in each graft fixation setting described below for kinematic evaluation.

sec.title: Graft Fixation Setting
sec.p: The grafts were provisionally fixed to the SE Graft Tensioning System (Linvatec) with sutures at the tibial site after the grafts had been fixed at the femoral side with the EndoButton CL-BTB (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy). The SE Graft Tensioning System (Linvatec) is a graft tensioning device that can help with quantifying and applying consistent amounts of tension to each graft, with an accuracy of 0.83 ± 0.03 N (mean ± standard deviation) according to the manufacturer’s guidelines. In this system, once the tension is set in the tensioning device, the excursion of the spring is locked. The advantage of this system is that the grafts are held securely in the tensioning system, allowing the graft to be cycled in line with the tunnel to remove the creep out of the construct (Figure 2).

caption.p: Stress Equalization (SE) Graft Tensioning System. Both the anteromedial bundle (AMB) and the posterolateral bundle (PLB) grafts were provisionally fixed to the graft tensioning system with sutures at the tibial site in each graft fixation setting. In this figure, tensions of the AMB and PLB are set to 30 N and 25 N, respectively.

sec.p: The graft fixation settings were as follows: (1) AMB only at 20° of flexion (A20), (2) PLB only at 20° of flexion (P20), (3) AMB fixation at 20° of flexion followed by PLB fixation at 0° of flexion (A20P0), (4) AMB fixation at 20° of flexion followed by PLB fixation at 20° of flexion (A20P20), and (5) AMB fixation at 20° of flexion followed by PLB fixation at 45° of flexion (A20P45). Diameter of the grafts was measured in 0.5-mm increments by using the slotted sizing block (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy), and applied tension to each graft was adjusted to be equal per cross-sectional area on a basis of 30 N per 6 mm in diameter, as shown in Table 1, so that both bundles were equally stress tensioned.5 A total graft tension of 40 N for hamstring tendons has been shown to be sufficient for restoring normal knee kinematics without causing joint overconstraint.33,37 We selected the stress value so that the total tension could become neither below 40 N nor too excessive. The creep of the construct was removed by repeatedly tightening the graft tensioning system with the knee being flexed and extended several times until the applied tension became stable. The testing order was A20P20 first, followed by A20, P20, A20P0, A20P45, and then A20P20 again for validation testing described later.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Applied tension to each graft was adjusted to be equal per cross-sectional area.

sec.title: Navigation Process
sec.p: The navigation system we used was the OrthoPilot ACL, version 2.2 (B. Braun-Aesculap, Tuttlingen, Germany), an image-free, wireless system that does not require preoperative computed tomography or intraoperative fluoroscopy. This system can provide not only the intra-articular positions of the tibial and femoral tunnels but also real-time calculation of AP tibial translation and internal-external tibial rotation at all degrees of knee flexion while the surgeon manipulates the joint. According to the manufacturer, the accuracy of the navigation is estimated to be less than 1 mm or less than 1°. All navigation processes (registration of knee kinematics and anatomic landmarks) were performed by a single surgeon (H.K.).

Before the navigation process, preoperative radiographic measurements, such as sagittal and transverse widths of the tibial plateau, length between the medial point of the tibial plateau and the spine of the medial intercondylar eminence, length between the anterior point of the tibial plateau and the spine of the medial intercondylar tubercle, and length of the Blumensaat line, were registered by the system. The femoral and tibial transmitters were firmly fixed to the femur and tibia with two 2.5-mm-diameter K-wires, respectively. Extra- and intra-articular landmarks were then registered by the system using a straight pointer or hook pointer. The extra-articular landmarks included the tibial tuberosity, the anterior edge of the tibia, and the medial and lateral points of the tibial plateau, which were determined at the skin level. The intra-articular landmarks included the anterior edge of the posterior cruciate ligament on the tibial plateau, the anterior horn of the lateral meniscus, the spine of the medial intercondylar tubercle, the anterior notch outlet, the lateral wall of the intercondylar notch, the 12-o’clock over-the-top position, and the lateral over-the-top position. The knee kinematics between 0° and 90° of knee flexion were also registered.

The navigation system was used to calculate manual maximum anterior tibial translation (ATT) and manual maximum internal rotation (IR) and external rotation (ER) of the tibia at 30° and 90° of knee flexion. All measurements were performed before graft insertion and in each graft fixation setting. All measurements were recorded under a manual maximum force applied by the same surgeon (H.K.) to minimize the interrater variability, who made every effort to apply a similar loading to the knee. All measurements were performed 3 times, and the results were averaged.

sec.title: Testing the Pivot-Shift Phenomenon
sec.p: The pivot-shift phenomenon was also evaluated before graft insertion and in each graft fixation setting. To evaluate the pivot-shift phenomenon, we used an N test.25 Namely, with the patient under anesthesia lying supine on an operating table, the examined extremity is lifted from the table, and the leg is extended from a position of 90° of flexion to full extension, while a valgus and IR moment is applied to the leg. Upon each test, the pivot-shift phenomenon was graded by a consensus of 2 examiners (T.M. and H.K.). The grading system we used was a modification of the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) criteria11 (grade 0 = negative; grade 1 = subtle glide but not negative; grade 2 = glide; grade 3 = between grade 2 and 4; grade 4 = clunk; grade 5 = between grade 4 and 6; grade 6 = gross) to more strictly evaluate the residual pivot-shift phenomenon. The number of pivot-shift–positive patients was compared among each setting, and knee kinematic data from the navigation system (ATT, IR, and ER at 30° and 90°) before graft insertion and in each setting that affected residual pivot-shift phenomenon were also evaluated to determine what kinematic data affected the residual pivot-shift phenomenon.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p: To validate the graft fixation procedure and the testing protocol, as well as to evaluate intrarater reliability, the first graft fixation setting was reapplied and retested after the completion of the biomechanical testing of the other graft fixation settings. The validation testing included manual maximum ATT, IR, and ER at 30° and 90° of knee flexion in the A20P20 setting, all of which were also performed 3 times, and the results were averaged.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Two-way repeated-measure ANOVA was used to compare each of the graft fixation settings and the state before graft insertion. Bonferroni-Dunn test was used for post hoc comparisons. Power analysis, with a power of 90% and an α of .05, demonstrated that a sample size of 10 patients was needed for the difference between A20P0 and A20P45 in IR at 30°. The Fisher exact probability test was used to compare the number of pivot-shift–positive cases among each setting. An unpaired Student t test was used to determine differences between pivot-shift–positive and –negative cases in relation to knee kinematic data from the navigation system before graft insertion and in each setting. For all analyses, statistical significance was set for P < .05. All kinematic data were reported as the mean ± standard deviation.

sec.title: Knee Kinematics
sec.p: Applied tensions to the AMB and PLB were 32 ± 2 N and 29 ± 3 N, respectively. All kinematic data are summarized in Table 2. In all graft fixation settings, ATT at 30°, ER at 30°, ATT at 90°, and ER at 90° were significantly decreased compared with the state before graft insertion. The IR at 30° was significantly decreased in all settings except for P20 compared with the state before graft insertion. On the other hand, IR at 90° was significantly decreased only in the A20P45 setting compared with the state before graft insertion.

In comparison with single- and double-bundle reconstruction settings, A20 was significantly less constrained than A20P20 and A20P45 in ATT at 30° (P = .027 and P = .006, respectively) and significantly less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30° (P = .017). However, there were no significant differences between A20 and A20P0. On the other hand, P20 was significantly less constrained than any other settings in ATT at 30° (A20, P = .043; A20P0, P = .0002; A20P20, P < .0001; A20P45, P < .0001) and significantly less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30° (P = .0007).

caption.p: Knee Kinematics Before Graft Insertion and in Each Graft Fixation Settinga

fn.label: a
fn.p: Data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. ATT30, anterior tibial translation at 30°; IR30, internal rotation at 30°; ER30, external rotation at 30°; ATT90, anterior tibial translation at 90°; IR90, internal rotation at 90°; ER90, external rotation at 90°.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Significant difference compared with data before graft insertion.

sec.p: In comparison with each graft fixation setting in double-bundle reconstruction, A20P0 was significantly less constrained than A20P45 in IR at 30° (P = .015) and ER at 30° (P = .049). However, there were no other significant differences among different settings.

sec.title: Pivot-Shift Phenomenon
sec.p: Test results of the pivot-shift phenomenon in each setting are shown in Table 3. Grades of the pivot-shift phenomenon were 3 or 4 in all cases before graft insertion. The pivot-shift phenomenon was resolved in all fixation settings in 3 cases; however, grade 1 pivot-shift phenomenon persisted in the P20 setting in 8 cases. Among those, 4 patients showed a grade 1 pivot-shift result in the A20 setting. Furthermore, 3 of the 4 cases also showed a grade 1 pivot-shift result in the A20P0 setting. Pivot-shift phenomenon was resolved in all cases in A20P20 and A20P45 settings. The number of pivot-shift cases in the P20 setting was significantly higher than that in the A20P20 or A20P45 setting (P = .001). However, there were no other significant differences among different settings, although there was a tendency that the number of pivot-shift cases in the A20 and A20P0 settings was higher than that in the A20P20 or A20P45 setting (P = .090 and P = .214, respectively).

fn.label: a
fn.p: Grade 0, negative; grade 1, subtle glide but not negative; grade 2, glide; grade 3, between grade 2 and 4; grade 4, clunk; grade 5, between grade 4 and 6; grade 6, gross.

sec.p: Knee kinematic data from the navigation system (ATT, IR, and ER at 30° and 90°) before graft insertion and in A20, P20, and A20P0 that affected residual pivot-shift phenomenon in each setting were also evaluated. None of the absolute values from either preoperative or each setting data showed any differences between pivot-shift–positive and –negative groups in each setting. However, in the P20 setting, differences between preoperative and each setting in IR at 30° and 90° were significantly smaller in the pivot-shift–positive group (Table 4).

caption.p: Differences in Pivot-Shift and Knee Kinematicsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Comparisons shown are between each setting and preoperative data. Data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. ATT30, anterior tibial translation at 30°; IR30, internal rotation at 30°; ER30, external rotation at 30°; ATT90, anterior tibial translation at 90°; IR90, internal rotation at 90°; ER90, external rotation at 90°.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Significant difference between pivot-shift–positive and –negative groups.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p: To validate the graft fixation procedure and intrarater reliability, the A20P20 setting was reapplied and retested after the completion of the biomechanical testing of all graft fixation settings. The mean absolute differences between the original test and validation test were 0.7 ± 0.8 mm in ATT at 30°, 1.6° ± 1.4° in IR at 30°, 1.2° ± 1.1° in ER at 30°, 0.6 ± 0.6 mm in ATT at 90°, 1.4° ± 1.7° in IR at 90°, and 1.1° ± 0.8° in ER at 90°.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, AP and rotational knee laxity in single AMB reconstruction, single PLB reconstruction, and 3 different combinations of graft fixation angles in double-bundle ACL reconstruction were evaluated. This was the first study to evaluate the effect of different graft fixation angles in double-bundle ACL reconstruction on knee kinematics in vivo, and the effect on pivot-shift phenomenon was also investigated. The results validated the first part of our hypotheses that the double-bundle ACL reconstruction controlled knee kinematics better than single AMB or PLB reconstruction in this study model, which by design utilized a single-bundle graft that was half the cross-sectional area of the double-bundle graft used. The ATT at 30° in A20P20 and A20P45 and IR at 30° in A20P45 were significantly decreased compared with those in single AMB reconstruction, while there were no differences between A20P0 and single AMB reconstruction. Differences between single PLB and double-bundle reconstruction were more remarkable. The ATT at 30° in all double-bundle settings and IR at 30° in A20P45 were significantly decreased compared with those in single PLB reconstruction. In the pivot-shift testing evaluated with our modified, stricter grading system in this study model, 8 cases showed grade 1 pivot-shift phenomenon in single PLB reconstruction and 4 cases in single AMB reconstruction, while pivot-shift phenomenon was resolved in all cases in the A20P20 and A20P45 settings of double-bundle reconstruction. The latter part of our hypotheses was partly validated, as IR at 30° and ER at 30° in A20P45 were significantly decreased compared with those in A20P0, and 3 cases showed residual grade 1 pivot-shift phenomenon only in the A20P0 setting. However, there were no other kinematic differences among those 3 settings.

Whether double-bundle reconstruction is superior to single AMB reconstruction, in terms of knee kinematics, is still a matter of controversy. In a cadaveric study, Yagi et al35 showed improved stability in double-bundle reconstruction under combined rotatory load. On the other hand, in recent in vivo studies, Ferretti et al8 and Miura et al21 demonstrated that both double-bundle and AMB reconstructions could similarly restore knee kinematics. This discrepancy could be explained by differences in graft fixation angles and applied initial tensions as well as graft diameter, graft source, tunnel placement, and graft fixation methods. Yagi et al35 fixed the AMB at 60° of knee flexion at 44 N and fixed the PLB at 15° of knee flexion at 44 N, whereas Miura et al21 fixed both bundles at 15° of knee flexion at 40 N. Ferretti et al8 fixed the AMB and PLB at the same angles as Yagi et al35; however, they did not validate applied initial tensions. Results from the present study also demonstrated that, with the applied tensions adjusted to be equal per cross-sectional area, double-bundle reconstruction controlled knee kinematics better than single AMB reconstruction when the AMB was fixed at 20° and the PLB was fixed at 20° or 45°, whereas there was no kinematic difference between double-bundle and single AMB reconstructions when the AMB was fixed at 20° and the PLB was fixed at 0°.

The inferiority of single PLB reconstruction to double-bundle reconstruction seemed evident in the present study model, as every double-bundle setting showed better AP stability at 30° of knee flexion and the A20P45 setting showed better internal rotatory stability at 30° of knee flexion (this may not be true for single-bundle reconstruction with the graft placed in current state-of-the-art single-bundle reconstructions because this technique was not investigated in this study). Our results seem to be in agreement with the findings of Tsai et al,29 who showed that ACL-deficient knees had increased ATT at 0° and 20° of knee flexion and IR of the tibia at 20° compared with that of the intact knee in the cadaveric study. In addition, 8 of 11 cases showed a slightly positive pivot-shift test finding in single PLB reconstruction. The IR at 30° was significantly less constrained in these 8 cases. These results indicate that single PLB reconstruction alone cannot restore normal knee kinematics at a slightly flexed knee position. On the other hand, we did not find any difference at 90° of knee flexion, as opposed to findings of Tsai et al29 and Miura et al,21 who demonstrated that ATT also increased at 90° of flexion. Their difference might have been because of a limited number of cases, a difference between cadaveric and in vivo studies, applied tensions, or graft fixation angles.

The effect of graft fixation angles on knee kinematics has been reported in many studies. Miura et al22 reported that fixation of both the AMB and PLB at 30° overloaded the PLB graft, whereas fixation of the AMB at 60° and PLB at 0° overloaded the AMB graft when each graft was tensioned to 22 N. In a later study, Vercillo et al31 reported that fixation of the AMB at 45° at 22 N and PLB at 15° at 22 N could more closely restore normal in situ force in the intact ACL. On the other hand, Murray et al23 recommended fixation of the AMB and PLB both at 20° at 22 N rather than fixation of the AMB at 45° at 22 N and PLB at 15° at 22 N, as the latter led to excessive tension in the AMB in full extension. In a recent study, Anderson et al2 demonstrated that as long as the PLB graft was fixed between 0° and 15°, the AMB graft could be fixed up to 75° without restricting knee laxity, while fixation of the PLB graft at 30° and above significantly overconstrained the knee when each graft was tensioned to 20 N. On the other hand, our results showed that IR at 30° was less constrained in the A20P0 setting than in the A20P45 setting. Three of 11 cases also showed a slightly positive pivot-shift finding in the A20P0 setting, while the pivot-shift phenomenon was resolved in all cases in the A20P20 and A20P45 settings. The discrepancy among these studies might have been because of the differences between in vivo and cadaveric studies (the present study was the first in vivo study) or differences in applied initial tension (the applied tension to the PLB was a little lower than the one to the AMB in the present study). Nevertheless, these results indicate that the PLB should not be fixed at 0° when the AMB is fixed at 20° with the applied tensions adjusted to be equal per cross-sectional area. The tension of the PLB is highest at full extension and is gradually relaxed with knee flexion.37 If the tension of the PLB abruptly decreases from full extension to 30°, its function could be decreased even in a slightly flexed position. This is also the case in a more deeply flexed position, as IR at 90° was significantly decreased only in the A20P45 setting compared with the state before graft insertion. These results might suggest that in clinical application, double-bundle reconstruction could fail to control rotational stability also unless the grafts were fixed in appropriate knee flexion angles. Therefore, additional research is needed to determine the effect of tension pattern on knee kinematics.

There were several limitations in this study. First, the forces to create the AP and rotational displacement were applied manually. However, the forces were applied by the same surgeon to minimize the interrater variability, who made every effort to apply a similar loading to the knee. All measurements were performed 3 times, and the results were averaged to minimize the intrarater variability, and the validation test showed good intrarater reliability.

It would have been much better if we could have evaluated the coupled anterior translation and IR during the pivot-shift test, ideally a mechanized one.12,19,24 However, the navigation system we used could not evaluate dynamic angle or translation changes during knee motion; that is, we had to measure them statically. Therefore, we decided to try to clarify how kinematic data against pure anterior translational or rotational load correlate to the subjective pivot-shift evaluations. In addition, the pivot-shift phenomenon was graded by a consensus of 2 examiners to minimize the interrater variability, and we tried to more strictly evaluate it using the modified IKDC criteria.

Sample size in this study might be too small to detect the differences in the number of pivot-shift–positive cases in each setting, although power analysis demonstrated that it was enough to detect the difference in IR at 30°. Still, we believe that it does not change the fact that fixation of the AMB at 20° and PLB at 0° might underconstrain the reconstructed knee.

We did not evaluate the effect of the fixation angle of the AMB graft, for example, comparing fixation of the AMB at 0° and 20°. However, a recent cadaveric study demonstrated that the AMB graft could be fixed up to 75° without restricting knee laxity, while fixation of the PLB graft at 30° and above significantly overconstrained the knee.2 We wanted to focus on the fixation angle of the PLB graft to clarify whether fixation of the PLB graft over 30° overconstrains the knee in clinical settings.

Another limitation was that the graft materials in the AMB or PLB reconstructions were only half the amount of those used in the double-bundle reconstructions. Differences in the applied total graft tension might affect the results as well, as the applied tensions in the AMB or PLB reconstructions were also only half the amount of those in the double-bundle reconstructions. In addition, the tunnel placements for the single-bundle reconstructions in this study were not the same as those for the state-of-the-art single-bundle reconstructions performed in clinical practice. Therefore, we could not draw any firm conclusions about superiority of double-bundle reconstructions. However, it was impossible to use the same sized grafts as double-bundle reconstruction settings or to make the same tunnel placements as clinically applied single-bundle reconstructions for single-bundle reconstruction settings in the present study in cases where clinical materials were used.

And most importantly, there was the lack of normal knee kinematics measured from the contralateral knee. With the invasive procedure of the navigation system, it was impossible to obtain kinematic data from contralateral normal knees. Therefore, we could not determine if the reconstructed knees were underconstrained or overconstrained. In addition, this study only determined the kinematics of the knee at the time of surgery. This model does not consider any changes that might occur after the surgery, such as tunnel-graft healing, tunnel motion, graft remodeling, and graft relaxation. Further investigations should be considered, such as development of a novel method to noninvasively and accurately measure AP and rotational stabilities or randomized controlled trials to determine the optimal graft fixation setting.

In conclusion, double-bundle ACL reconstruction with fixation of the AMB at 20° and PLB at 20° or 45° restored better stability than single AMB or single PLB reconstruction in which the graft was of smaller size in this in vivo laboratory model. In double-bundle reconstruction, different graft fixation angles affected knee kinematics and pivot-shift phenomenon at the time of surgery. Fixation of the PLB at 0° might underconstrain the reconstructed knee compared with that of the PLB at 20° or 45°, when the AMB is fixed at 20° and applied initial tension is adjusted to be equal per cross-sectional area, with the individual variability that should lead to caution until it can be better assessed clinically by surgeons.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
